messages: a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (12:38): Has the <q> thread managed to come up with a solution that allows using <q> in languages that puts the following punctuation within the quote marks?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (12:39): I must admit to skimming the most outrageous quote trains :)

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:43): I wonder if I'd only contribute to the damage done by the denial of productivity effect of <q> if I pointed out some of its history in order to make a point that the semantic need is questionable...

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:58): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9, although I really hate that convention, the solution is to put the punctuation within the <q> element if that's what you need.
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:58): IMHO, punctuation should only be within the quote marks if it is part of the quote itself, otherwise it should go after.
5e3a8698bf6602e718ae1e2be4d3afeb (13:03): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220, but there are plenty of people who disagree with you :)
5e3a8698bf6602e718ae1e2be4d3afeb (13:03): (myself not included, though)
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (13:03): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: But that's just plain _wrong_ when the punctuation isn't part of the quote

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:08): The correct method of quoting is obvious in the computerised world: you copy-and-paste what someone else wrote, put quotation marks around it, and then put all your extra words and punctuation outside the quotes
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:09): The old world didn't have copy-and-paste, so they could be excused for doing silly things like adding punctuation inside quotes instead :-)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:10): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: I disagree with you in the case of en-US. :-)

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:11): one of the many problems with <q> is that languages high up in the pecking order (en-US and fr-FR) are illogical in the sense that quotation marks do not strictly delimit the quoted string
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:13): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9, what exactly is wrong with what I said?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:14): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: what's wrong is that implementing what you said for en-US is economically a bad idea
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:14): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: which inline box model bugs would you forgo the fixes for while top hackers implement punctuation flipping?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:14): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, I think you misunderstood what I said
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (13:15): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: HTML does not have a mandate to change national languages

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:16): if the punctuation should be within the quote marks, then the author should put it within the <q> element. e.g. <q>Some quote.</q> --> "Some quote." Otherwise, the author should put it outside. e.g. <q>Some quote</q>. --> "Some quote".
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:17): notes that IE8b2 (at least on an en-GB system) seems to use single quotes for <q> by default, and double quotes once you add lang=en
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:17): whoa. gsnedders isn't here today.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:17): he has a copy of The Handbook, right?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (13:18): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: No, it seems you're suggesting mangling the quote instead
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (13:19): The trailing punctuation is not necessarily part of the quote
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:19): It's not me mangling the quotes, it's the illogical languages that incorrectly stick punctuation within quotation marks where it doesn't belong.
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:20): that's why I said "IMHO, punctuation should only be within the quote marks if it is part of the quote itself, otherwise it should go after."
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (13:20): Yes, but as I said, we don't go around changing languages

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:21): sees that IE8b2 does 'x"y"z' for default <q> (on an en-GB system), "x'y'z" if lang=en or lang=en-xx where xx is not gb, and those double/single chevron things if lang=fr
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:22): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c, so does it do "x'y'z" for en-AU?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:22): (When I say """ and "'", I mean the curly equivalents)
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:23): (I'm not sure what the correct way is supposed to be, but I always do it that way)
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:24): so is it doing that based on the system's own language settings when it isn't explicitly declared in the page?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:24): lang=no has funny quotes
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:24): (Double-chevron, then comma/apostrophe or something)

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:25): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: I don't know - I'd need to change my system's language settings to test that, but I'm not sure how (and don't have time now)
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:25): wonders what a Double-chevron is
